141B: Lesson 12

Parsing HTML and XML

HTML

We have already seen basic syntax for hypertext markup language (HTML), and really that is all that you need. Just know that there are tags, such as div, a, body, span that will wrap more markup. This happens by the use of openning and closing tags <div class='example'>text in between</div> where the closing tag matches the openning tag, except there is an additional /. The tag has a name, div, and some attributes, such as class='example'. When request an html file from a url, it is returned as a string, and you will need to process the html. BeautifulSoup and lxml can help with that by parsing it based on the tags. If a tag is nested inside of another tag then we say that that tag is a child of the other. This means that the tags will naturally have a tree structure. This is because tree structures require relationships between objects to be a parent-child type, so that each element branches to its children. For example, the HTML, <div><p>text 1</p><span>text 1</span></div> has a div tag with children p and span. Each of these have accompanying text. BeautifulSoup will help you navigate this tree structure.

Checkpoint: Go through the documentation front page and install BeautifulSoup through conda.

The following videos are based on the jupyter notebook. In it we will web-scrape the data.gov cite for climate change related datasets. While this only goes through HTML, XML has the same structure, so parsing it will be the same.
